title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others‚Äô private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement sshafee@isrt.ac.bd. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla‚Äôs code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: First , thanks taking time contribute skmisc! types contributions encouraged valued. See Table contents different ways help details project handles . Please make sure read relevant section making contribution. make lot easier us maintainers smooth experience involved.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: Code conduct Style guide Commit messages Asking questions Reporting bugs Requesting features Contributing code

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: project released Contributor Code Conduct. participating, expected uphold code. Please report unacceptable behavior sshafee@isrt.ac.bd.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: use Tidyverse style guide writing R code. Functions documented roxygen2 syntax. skmisc uses lower_snake_case.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: want contribute commiting changes, please try use Conventional commits specification.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: ask question, best search existing Issues might help . case found suitable issue still need clarification, can write question issue. still feel need ask question need clarification, recommend following: Open new Issue. Use template other_issue.md. Provide much context can ‚Äôre running . Provide project platform versions (paste output sessionInfo()). take care issue soon possible.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: good bug report shouldn‚Äôt leave others needing chase information. Therefore, ask investigate carefully, collect information describe issue detail report. Please complete following steps advance help us fix potential bug fast possible. Make sure using latest version skmisc. Determine bug really bug error side. see users experienced (potentially already solved) issue , check already bug report existing bug error bug tracker.

what: How do I submit a bug report?
title: Contributing to skmisc
text: use GitHub Issues track bugs errors. run issue project: Open new Issue. Use template bug_report.md. Explain behavior expect actual behavior. Please provide much context possible describe reproduction steps someone else can follow recreate issue . usually includes code reproducible example. take care issue soon possible.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: Make sure using latest version skmisc. Read documentation carefully find functionality already covered. Perform search see enhancement already suggested. , add comment existing issue instead opening new one.

what: How do I submit a feature request?
title: Contributing to skmisc
text: Feature requests tracked GitHub Issues. Open new Issue. Use template feature_request.md. Provide clear descriptive title issue identify suggestion. Provide step--step description suggested enhancement many details possible. Explain enhancement useful skmisc users. take care issue soon possible.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: use GitHub flow collaborate project: Fork repository using GitHub interface. Clone fork using git clone fork-url (replace fork-url URL fork). Alternatively, open RStudio IDE create New Project Version Control. Create new branch w/ git checkout -b branch-name (replace branch-name name new branch). Make contribution (see examples). Stage (git add) commit (git commit) changes often necessary Push changes GitHub w/ git push origin branch-name. Submit Pull Request original repo. review PR soon possible.

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: want contribute improving README, please edit README.Rmd (README.md). forget update README.md running:
code: rmarkdown::render("README.Rmd")

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: want contribute editing existing vignette, just edit corresponding Rmd file stored vignettes/ folder. want contribute adding new vignette, create new Rmd file vignettes/ folder add following header: use new external dependency, forget add DESCRIPTION file section Suggests (package already listed section Imports). Check integrity package :
code: --- title: "Vignette Title" output: rmarkdown::html_vignette vignette: >   %\VignetteIndexEntry{Vignette Title}   %\VignetteEngine{knitr::rmarkdown}   %\VignetteEncoding{UTF-8} --- devtools::check()

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: want contribute improving documentation function, open corresponding file R/ folder edit lines starting #' (roxygen2 syntax). Update documentation (Rd files man/ folder) running: use new external dependency example section, forget add DESCRIPTION file section Imports (package already listed). Check integrity package :
code: devtools::document() devtools::check()

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: want contribute improving code function, open edit corresponding file R/ folder. Check integrity package : forget adapt unit tests function editing corresponding file stored tests/testthat/ folder. use package testthat implement unit tests. Check tests running:
code: devtools::check() devtools::test()

title: Contributing to skmisc
text: want contribute submitting new feature, please follow workflow: Create new R file folder R/. Implement code function. Document function w/ roxygen2 syntax. necessary, add additional dependencies DESCRIPTION file. Update package documentation w/ devtools::document(). Create new R file folder tests/testthat/. Implement unit tests new function. Check integrity package w/ devtools::check(). Thanks contribution!

what: Create a Structured Article Template for a Journal Supported by {rticles}
title: An R package providing miscellaneous functions by Shafayet Khan
text: Suppose want format manuscript following Statistics Medicine (SIM) style using R package rticles. standard approach : creates directory named sim_article working directory, containing files required SIM format. structure looks like : works well, structure one limitation: must write entire manuscript single Rmd file. However, personally prefer keeping different major sections separate Rmd files better organization modular editing. motivated creation following function: Running create directory sim_article modular structure: layout, major section lives Rmd file, main file (sim_article.Rmd) includes child documents. example (non-essential YAML omitted): check formatted pdf , just knit main sim_article.Rmd file. structure allows keep manuscript clean, organized, modular. Useful, innit? üôÇ [!NOTE] function skmisc::create_article_template() convenient wrapper around rmarkdown::draft() lets use rticles journal format working multiple Rmd files. prefer traditional single-file workflow, simply use rmarkdown::draft() rticles directly.
code: rmarkdown::draft(     "sim_article",      template = "sim",      package = "rticles",     create_dir = TRUE,     edit = FALSE ) sim_article ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bibfile.bib ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Fonts ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Stix ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ LETTERSP.STY ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ skeleton.log ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sim_article.Rmd ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ WileyNJD-AMA.bst ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ WileyNJD-v5.cls skmisc::create_article_template("sim") sim_article ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ abstract.Rmd ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bibfile.bib ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Example.Rmd ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Fonts ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Stix ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ LETTERSP.STY ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sections ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ section01.Rmd ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ section02.Rmd ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ section03.Rmd ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ section04.Rmd ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ section05.Rmd ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sim_article.Rmd ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ skeleton.log ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ WileyNJD-AMA.bst ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ WileyNJD-v5.cls --- <..TRUNCATED..> abstract: |     `r paste(readLines("abstract.Rmd"), collapse = "\n  ")` <..TRUNCATED..> ---  ```{r section01, child="sections/section01.Rmd"} ```  ```{r section02, child="sections/section02.Rmd"} ```  ```{r section03, child="sections/section03.Rmd"} ```  ```{r section04, child="sections/section04.Rmd"} ```  ```{r section05, child="sections/section05.Rmd"} ```

what: Converting the title of bib entries in a bib file to title case
title: An R package providing miscellaneous functions by Shafayet Khan
code:
library(skmisc)  bib_file <- system.file("extdata", "ref.bib", package = "skmisc")  # The original bib entries cat(readLines(bib_file), sep = "
") #> @article{merlo2005brief, #>   title={A brief conceptual tutorial of multilevel analysis in social epidemiology: linking the statistical concept of clustering to the idea of contextual phenomenon}, #>   author={Merlo, Juan and Chaix, Basile and Yang, Min and Lynch, John and R{\aa}stam, Lennart}, #>   journal={Journal of Epidemiology \& Community Health}, #>   volume={59}, #>   number={6}, #>   pages={443--449}, #>   year={2005}, #>   publisher={BMJ Publishing Group Ltd} #> } #>  #> @inproceedings{hox1998multilevel, #>   title={Multilevel modeling: When and why}, #>   author={Hox, Joop}, #>   booktitle={Classification, data analysis, and data highways: proceedings of the 21st Annual Conference of the Gesellschaft f{"u}r Klassifikation eV, University of Potsdam, March 12--14, 1997}, #>   pages={147--154}, #>   year={1998}, #>   organization={Springer} #> }  # Convert all supported components (default) tmp_all <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib") bib_title_case(   bib_file_path = bib_file,   output_bib_file = tmp_all ) #> ! Invalid booktitle string: NA in the bib file #> ! Expected a single, non-NA character string; using empty string instead #> ! Invalid journal string: NA in the bib file #> ! Expected a single, non-NA character string; using empty string instead #> ‚úî Successfully wrote BibTeX file: #>   '/var/folders/1b/qtkmxx654wngfv_28qzz60l00000gn/T//RtmpvNOFEM/file13f64160bb7e0.bib' cat(readLines(tmp_all), sep = "
") #> @Article{merlo2005brief, #>   title = {{A Brief Conceptual Tutorial of Multilevel Analysis in Social Epidemiology: Linking the Statistical Concept of Clustering to the Idea of Contextual Phenomenon}}, #>   author = {Juan Merlo and Basile Chaix and Min Yang and John Lynch and Lennart R{ a}stam}, #>   journal = {{Journal of Epidemiology \& Community Health}}, #>   volume = {59}, #>   number = {6}, #>   pages = {443--449}, #>   year = {2005}, #>   publisher = {BMJ Publishing Group Ltd}, #>   booktitle = {{}}, #> } #>  #> @InProceedings{hox1998multilevel, #>   title = {{Multilevel Modeling: When and Why}}, #>   author = {Joop Hox}, #>   journal = {{}}, #>   pages = {147--154}, #>   year = {1998}, #>   booktitle = {{Classification, Data Analysis, and Data Highways: Proceedings of the 21st Annual Conference of the Gesellschaft F{"u}r Klassifikation eV, University of Potsdam, March 12--14, 1997}}, #>   organization = {Springer}, #> }  # Convert only the title field tmp_title_only <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib") bib_title_case(   bib_file_path = bib_file,   output_bib_file = tmp_title_only,   components = "title" ) #> ‚úî Successfully wrote BibTeX file: #>   '/var/folders/1b/qtkmxx654wngfv_28qzz60l00000gn/T//RtmpvNOFEM/file13f6420d7369a.bib' cat(readLines(tmp_title_only), sep = "
") #> @Article{merlo2005brief, #>   title = {{A Brief Conceptual Tutorial of Multilevel Analysis in Social Epidemiology: Linking the Statistical Concept of Clustering to the Idea of Contextual Phenomenon}}, #>   author = {Juan Merlo and Basile Chaix and Min Yang and John Lynch and Lennart R{ a}stam}, #>   journal = {Journal of Epidemiology \& Community Health}, #>   volume = {59}, #>   number = {6}, #>   pages = {443--449}, #>   year = {2005}, #>   publisher = {BMJ Publishing Group Ltd}, #> } #>  #> @InProceedings{hox1998multilevel, #>   title = {{Multilevel Modeling: When and Why}}, #>   author = {Joop Hox}, #>   pages = {147--154}, #>   year = {1998}, #>   booktitle = {Classification, data analysis, and data highways: proceedings of the 21st Annual Conference of the Gesellschaft f{"u}r Klassifikation eV, University of Potsdam, March 12--14, 1997}, #>   organization = {Springer}, #> }  # Convert title and journal fields only tmp_title_journal <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib") bib_title_case(   bib_file_path = bib_file,   output_bib_file = tmp_title_journal,   components = c("title", "journal") ) #> ! Invalid journal string: NA in the bib file #> ! Expected a single, non-NA character string; using empty string instead #> ‚úî Successfully wrote BibTeX file: #>   '/var/folders/1b/qtkmxx654wngfv_28qzz60l00000gn/T//RtmpvNOFEM/file13f641141c94e.bib' cat(readLines(tmp_title_journal), sep = "
") #> @Article{merlo2005brief, #>   title = {{A Brief Conceptual Tutorial of Multilevel Analysis in Social Epidemiology: Linking the Statistical Concept of Clustering to the Idea of Contextual Phenomenon}}, #>   author = {Juan Merlo and Basile Chaix and Min Yang and John Lynch and Lennart R{ a}stam}, #>   journal = {{Journal of Epidemiology \& Community Health}}, #>   volume = {59}, #>   number = {6}, #>   pages = {443--449}, #>   year = {2005}, #>   publisher = {BMJ Publishing Group Ltd}, #> } #>  #> @InProceedings{hox1998multilevel, #>   title = {{Multilevel Modeling: When and Why}}, #>   author = {Joop Hox}, #>   journal = {{}}, #>   pages = {147--154}, #>   year = {1998}, #>   booktitle = {Classification, data analysis, and data highways: proceedings of the 21st Annual Conference of the Gesellschaft f{"u}r Klassifikation eV, University of Potsdam, March 12--14, 1997}, #>   organization = {Springer}, #> }

what: Convert the title, booktitle, journal name of each bibentry of a bib file to title case. ‚Äî bib_title_case
title: Convert the title, booktitle, journal name of each bibentry of a bib file to title case. ‚Äî bib_title_case
text: Convert title, booktitle, journal name bibentry bib file title case.

title: Convert the title, booktitle, journal name of each bibentry of a bib file to title case. ‚Äî bib_title_case
code: bib_title_case(   bib_file_path,   output_bib_file,   components = "all",   overwrite = FALSE )

title: Convert the title, booktitle, journal name of each bibentry of a bib file to title case. ‚Äî bib_title_case
text: bib_file_path character, path .bib file. output_bib_file character, path .bib file contain transformed bib-entries title-cased title. components Character vector specifying BibTeX fields converted title case. Valid values include "title", "booktitle", "journal". special value "" (default) applies transformation supported fields. fields listed components present input .bib file modified. Fields included components left unchanged. Examples: components = "" (default): modify title, booktitle, journal name components = "title": modify article titles components = c("title", "journal"): modify title journal name overwrite Logical. existing output file overwritten? Defaults FALSE. FALSE file already exists, function abort informative message. TRUE, existing file replaced.

title: Convert the title, booktitle, journal name of each bibentry of a bib file to title case. ‚Äî bib_title_case
text: output_bib_file character string, invisibly.

title: Convert the title, booktitle, journal name of each bibentry of a bib file to title case. ‚Äî bib_title_case
code: # Example .bib file included with the package bib_file <- system.file("extdata", "ref.bib", package = "skmisc")  # Temporary output file tmp_output_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib")  # Convert all supported components (default) bib_title_case(   bib_file_path = bib_file,   output_bib_file = tmp_output_file ) #> ! Invalid booktitle string: NA in the bib file #> ! Expected a single, non-NA character string; using empty string instead #> ! Invalid journal string: NA in the bib file #> ! Expected a single, non-NA character string; using empty string instead #> ‚úî Successfully wrote BibTeX file: /tmp/RtmpdR1gB7/file184e243a7db7.bib cat(readLines(tmp_output_file), sep = "\n") #> @Article{merlo2005brief, #>   title = {{A Brief Conceptual Tutorial of Multilevel Analysis in Social Epidemiology: Linking the Statistical Concept of Clustering to the Idea of Contextual Phenomenon}}, #>   author = {Juan Merlo and Basile Chaix and Min Yang and John Lynch and Lennart R{\r a}stam}, #>   journal = {{Journal of Epidemiology \& Community Health}}, #>   volume = {59}, #>   number = {6}, #>   pages = {443--449}, #>   year = {2005}, #>   publisher = {BMJ Publishing Group Ltd}, #>   booktitle = {{}}, #> } #>  #> @InProceedings{hox1998multilevel, #>   title = {{Multilevel Modeling: When and Why}}, #>   author = {Joop Hox}, #>   journal = {{}}, #>   pages = {147--154}, #>   year = {1998}, #>   booktitle = {{Classification, Data Analysis, and Data Highways: Proceedings of the 21st Annual Conference of the Gesellschaft F{\"u}r Klassifikation eV, University of Potsdam, March 12--14, 1997}}, #>   organization = {Springer}, #> }  # Convert only the title field tmp_title_only <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib") bib_title_case(   bib_file_path = bib_file,   output_bib_file = tmp_title_only,   components = "title" ) #> ‚úî Successfully wrote BibTeX file: /tmp/RtmpdR1gB7/file184e44eda3bf.bib  # Convert title and journal fields only tmp_title_journal <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib") bib_title_case(   bib_file_path = bib_file,   output_bib_file = tmp_title_journal,   components = c("title", "journal") ) #> ! Invalid journal string: NA in the bib file #> ! Expected a single, non-NA character string; using empty string instead #> ‚úî Successfully wrote BibTeX file: /tmp/RtmpdR1gB7/file184e26f2472f.bib

what: Check a numeric value against a single bound ‚Äî check_bound
title: Check a numeric value against a single bound ‚Äî check_bound
text: function validates numeric variable satisfies specified bound. allows check lower upper bounds, choose whether bound inclusive exclusive. value meet bound, styled error raised using cli::cli_abort().

title: Check a numeric value against a single bound ‚Äî check_bound
code: check_bound(val, bound, include = TRUE, is_lower = TRUE)

title: Check a numeric value against a single bound ‚Äî check_bound
text: val Numeric variable check. bound Numeric bound compare . include Logical; TRUE, bound inclusive (>= <=), otherwise exclusive (> <). Default TRUE. is_lower Logical; TRUE, bound treated lower bound, otherwise upper bound. Default TRUE.

title: Check a numeric value against a single bound ‚Äî check_bound
text: Invisibly returns TRUE. Throws error class rlang::rlang_error variable violates bound.

title: Check a numeric value against a single bound ‚Äî check_bound
code: check_bound(0.5, 0)                # passes, lower bound inclusive check_bound(0.5, 1, is_lower = FALSE) # passes, upper bound not relevant if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ check_bound(-0.1, 0)              # throws error check_bound(1.1, 1)               # throws error } # }

code: check_char_scalar("hello")      # passes check_char_scalar("  hi  ")     # passes if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ check_char_scalar("")           # error check_char_scalar("   ")        # error check_char_scalar(42)           # error check_char_scalar(c("a", "b"))  # error check_char_scalar(NA)           # error check_char_scalar(NULL)         # error } # }

what: Check whether a variable is within a specified numerical bounds. ‚Äî check_numeric_bound

text: Check whether variable within specified numerical bounds.

title: Check whether a variable is within a specified numerical bounds. ‚Äî check_numeric_bound
text: x variable validate. lower Numerical lower bound. Default 0. upper Numerical upper bound. Default 1. lower_include Logical; TRUE, lower bound inclusive, otherwise exclusive. Default TRUE. upper_include Logical; TRUE, upper bound inclusive, otherwise exclusive. Default TRUE.

title: Check whether a variable is within a specified numerical bounds. ‚Äî check_numeric_bound
text: Invisibly returns TRUE checks pass; Otherwise, throws error class rlang::rlang_error.

title: Check whether a variable is within a specified numerical bounds. ‚Äî check_numeric_bound
code: check_numeric_bound(0.5) # within [0, 1] check_numeric_bound(0, lower_include = TRUE) check_numeric_bound(1, upper_include = TRUE)  # Exclusive bounds check_numeric_bound(0.5, lower_include = FALSE, upper_include = FALSE)  # Custom bounds check_numeric_bound(10, lower = 5, upper = 20)  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Error cases: check_numeric_bound(NA) check_numeric_bound("a") check_numeric_bound(2, upper = 1) check_numeric_bound(0, lower_include = FALSE) } # }

text: Invisibly returns TRUE check pass. Throws error class rlang::rlang_error check fail.

title: Check whether an object is a valid numeric scalar ‚Äî check_numeric_scalar

what: Create a structured article template directory for a specified journal ‚Äî create_article_template
title: Create a structured article template directory for a specified journal ‚Äî create_article_template
text: Generates ready--use article template journal supported rticles package. function creates draft rmarkdown::draft(), sets clean directory structure (separate sections/ folder abstract.Rmd file), moves abstract texts YAML front-matter, inserts child-document chunks five default sections, formats <journal_name>_article.Rmd file section chunks abstract.

title: Create a structured article template directory for a specified journal ‚Äî create_article_template
code: create_article_template(journal_name)

title: Create a structured article template directory for a specified journal ‚Äî create_article_template
text: journal_name Character string giving name journal. Must one journals returned rticles::journals().

title: Create a structured article template directory for a specified journal ‚Äî create_article_template
text: Invisibly returns path created directory. function called primarily side effect creating files disk.

title: Create a structured article template directory for a specified journal ‚Äî create_article_template
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ create_article_template("arxiv") create_article_template("peerj") } # }

what: Test whether an object is strictly a boolean scalar ‚Äî is_bool_scalar
title: Test whether an object is strictly a boolean scalar ‚Äî is_bool_scalar
text: function checks whether x exactly TRUE exactly FALSE. uses base::identical() ensure strict checking type, length, value. Values missing, invalid (per is_invalid()), single logical scalar always return FALSE.

title: Test whether an object is strictly a boolean scalar ‚Äî is_bool_scalar
code: is_bool_scalar(x)

title: Test whether an object is strictly a boolean scalar ‚Äî is_bool_scalar
text: x R object check.

title: Test whether an object is strictly a boolean scalar ‚Äî is_bool_scalar
text: logical scalar: TRUE x exactly TRUE FALSE, otherwise FALSE.

title: Test whether an object is strictly a boolean scalar ‚Äî is_bool_scalar
code: is_bool_scalar(TRUE)                 # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_bool_scalar(FALSE)                # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_bool_scalar(NA)                   # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_bool_scalar(c(TRUE, FALSE))       # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_bool_scalar("TRUE")               # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_bool_scalar(1L)                   # FALSE #> [1] FALSE

what: Test whether an object is a single, non-empty character string ‚Äî is_char_scalar
title: Test whether an object is a single, non-empty character string ‚Äî is_char_scalar
text: function checks whether object scalar character string NULL, NA, empty trimming whitespace. function relies is_invalid() detect unusable inputs NULL, zero-length vectors, error objects.

title: Test whether an object is a single, non-empty character string ‚Äî is_char_scalar
code: is_char_scalar(x)

title: Test whether an object is a single, non-empty character string ‚Äî is_char_scalar
text: x R object validate.

title: Test whether an object is a single, non-empty character string ‚Äî is_char_scalar
text: TRUE x single, non-missing, non-empty character string trimming; otherwise FALSE.

title: Test whether an object is a single, non-empty character string ‚Äî is_char_scalar
code: is_char_scalar("hello")     # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_char_scalar("  hi  ")    # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_char_scalar("   ")       # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_char_scalar("")          # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_char_scalar(1)           # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_char_scalar(NA)          # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_char_scalar(NULL)        # FALSE #> [1] FALSE

what: Test whether an object is considered invalid ‚Äî is_invalid
title: Test whether an object is considered invalid ‚Äî is_invalid
text: function tests whether R object considered invalid. object invalid meets following conditions: base::missing(), NULL, zero length, inherits class "try-error", inherits class "simpleError", list whose elements invalid (checked recursively), atomic vector whose elements NA.

title: Test whether an object is considered invalid ‚Äî is_invalid
code: is_invalid(x)

title: Test whether an object is considered invalid ‚Äî is_invalid
text: x R object check.

title: Test whether an object is considered invalid ‚Äî is_invalid
text: logical scalar: TRUE object invalid, FALSE otherwise.

title: Test whether an object is considered invalid ‚Äî is_invalid
text: Lists validated recursively: list invalid every element list invalid. Atomic vectors considered invalid values NA.

title: Test whether an object is considered invalid ‚Äî is_invalid
code: is_invalid(NULL)                 # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_invalid(character(0))         # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_invalid(c(NA, NA))            # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_invalid(c(1, NA))             # FALSE #> [1] FALSE  is_invalid(list(NA, NULL))       # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_invalid(list(NA, 5))          # FALSE #> [1] FALSE  # try-error example err1 <- try(stop("err"), silent = TRUE) is_invalid(err1)                 # TRUE #> [1] TRUE  # simpleError example err2 <- simpleError("oops") is_invalid(err2)                 # TRUE #> [1] TRUE  is_invalid(5)                    # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_invalid("txt")                # FALSE #> [1] FALSE

what: Check whether an object is a valid numeric scalar ‚Äî is_numeric_scalar
title: Check whether an object is a valid numeric scalar ‚Äî is_numeric_scalar
text: function tests whether input valid numeric scalar: NULL, NA, non-finite, length one. first checks invalid inputs using is_invalid(), verifies value numeric, length one, finite.

title: Check whether an object is a valid numeric scalar ‚Äî is_numeric_scalar
code: is_numeric_scalar(x)

title: Check whether an object is a valid numeric scalar ‚Äî is_numeric_scalar
text: x object test.

title: Check whether an object is a valid numeric scalar ‚Äî is_numeric_scalar
text: TRUE x valid numeric scalar; otherwise FALSE.

title: Check whether an object is a valid numeric scalar ‚Äî is_numeric_scalar
code: is_numeric_scalar(1)       # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_numeric_scalar(3.14)    # TRUE #> [1] TRUE is_numeric_scalar(NA)      # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_numeric_scalar(NULL)    # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_numeric_scalar(c(1, 2)) # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_numeric_scalar(Inf)     # FALSE #> [1] FALSE

what: skmisc: Miscellaneous Functions by Shafayet Khan ‚Äî skmisc-package
title: skmisc: Miscellaneous Functions by Shafayet Khan ‚Äî skmisc-package
text: Contains function makes certain workflows easier.

title: skmisc: Miscellaneous Functions by Shafayet Khan ‚Äî skmisc-package
text: Maintainer: Shafayet Khan Shafee sshafee@isrt.ac.bd (ORCID) [copyright holder]

title: skmisc 0.6.0
text: Added several type validation functions (is_*_scalar) robust input checks, including: is_bool_scalar() ‚Äì check value exactly TRUE FALSE is_char_scalar() ‚Äì check value single non-empty character is_numeric_scalar() ‚Äì check value single numeric scalar Added corresponding checker functions raise error validation fails, e.g.: check_bool_scalar(TRUE) passes, check_bool_scalar(NA) throws rlang_error check_char_scalar("hello") passes, check_char_scalar(" ") throws rlang_error check_numeric_scalar(0.5) passes, check_numeric_scalar(NA) throws rlang_error Made is_* check_* functions consistent naming behavior. Added comprehensive testthat tests validation check functions.

title: skmisc 0.5.0
text: Output directory tree created article template

title: skmisc 0.4.0
text: Added many checks tests create_article_template bib_title_case Modularized & refactored bib_title_case better testing made function robust process. Enhanced function error, warning simple messages. Linted package code using lintr formatted code using air

title: skmisc 0.3.0
text: Renamed funciton bib_title_to_title_case bib_title_case used lifecycle::deprecate_warn.

title: skmisc 0.2.0
text: Added components argument selectively title-case fields ("title", "booktitle", "journal") "" fields (‚Äú‚Äù default). Added overwrite argument control whether existing output files replaced. Used safe_title_case() helper protect text inside braces safely apply title case. Input/output validation improved using fs cli robust error messages. Refactored component processing loop: fast, safe, avoids code duplication. Internal helpers is_char_scalar() wrap_braces_once() added.

title: skmisc 0.1.3
text: Updated bib_title_to_title_case use multi-line cli message formatting. Added cli message formatting create_article_template. Started using R package cli format package messages consistently.

title: skmisc 0.1.2
text: Added create_article_template() function generates article template specified journal using rmarkdown::draft function rticles package. checks whether journal supported, creates necessary directories files, formats article rmarkdown file adding section chunks abstract.

title: skmisc 0.1.1
text: Modified bib_title_to_title_case() adding curly brackets title title casing gets preserved.

title: skmisc 0.1.0
text: Added first function bib_title_to_title_case()
